title: Records - Grouping Related Data
description: Learn how to group different types of data together using records

content.introduction:
Records allow you to group different types of data together under a single name. Unlike arrays (which store multiple values of the same type), records can store different types of data as a logical unit.

Think of a record as a custom data type that represents a real-world entity (like a person, product, or book) with various attributes.

### What You'll Learn
- Declaring record types
- Creating record variables
- Accessing record fields
- Using records with arrays
- Nested records

concepts.title: Record Declaration
concepts.description: Define a new record type in the 'type' section, specifying the fields and their types

concepts.title: Record Fields
concepts.description: Individual data elements within a record. Access using dot notation: recordVar.fieldName

concepts.title: Record Variables
concepts.description: Declare variables using your record type, just like any other type

concepts.title: Arrays of Records
concepts.description: Combine arrays and records to store collections of structured data

exercises.title: Book Record
exercises.description: Create a record type for a book with fields for Title, Author, Year, and Pages. Create a variable and display the book information.
hints: Define the record type in the 'type' section
Use String for text fields (Title, Author)
Use Integer for numeric fields (Year, Pages)
Access fields using dot notation: book.Title

exercises.title: Point Distance
exercises.description: Create a record for a 2D point with X and Y coordinates. Create two points and calculate the distance between them using the formula: √((x2-x1)² + (y2-y1)²)
hints: Calculate the difference in X coordinates (dx)
Calculate the difference in Y coordinates (dy)
Square both differences and add them
Use Sqrt() function to get the square root
The distance from (0,0) to (3,4) should be 5.00

exercises.title: Movie Collection
exercises.description: Create a TMovie record and an array to store 3 movies. Display all movies with their ratings and find the highest-rated movie.
hints: Define fields for Title (String), Director (String), Year (Integer), and Rating (Real)
Use an array of TMovie to store 3 movies
Track the index of the highest-rated movie
Compare ratings in a loop to find the best one

content.summary:
Great work! You've mastered records:

- Defining record types in the `type` section
- Creating record variables
- Accessing fields with dot notation: `record.field`
- Combining records with arrays
- Creating nested records for complex data

Records are perfect for organizing related data of different types into logical units, making your code more readable and maintainable!
content.nextSteps: Next, you'll learn about **Sets** - a special data type for working with groups of related values, perfect for membership testing and set operations.
